DOCNAME: CASE OF EREMIASOVA AND PECHOVA v. THE CZECH REPUBLIC
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 2 - Right to life (Article 2-1 - Life) (Substantive aspect);Violation of Article 2 - Right to life (Article 2-1 - Effective investigation) (Procedural aspect)
JUDGES: André Potocki;Ann Power-Forde;Dean Spielmann;Elisabet Fura;Ganna Yudkivska;Karel Jungwiert;Mark Villiger
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants are NORP nationals who were born in DATE and DATE respectively , and live in GPE .
CARDINAL . According to police records , on DATE ORG , partner of the first

applicant who gave birth to his child in DATE and son of the second , of GPE origin , was arrested by the police on suspicion of having committed a burglary and transported to FAC ( the “ ORG ” ) . Having been questioned TIME and TIME , he was charged with illegal entry into a dwelling and theft at TIME

CARDINAL . According to the statement made by the police officers , at TIME , PERSON had been situated in the separate waiting - room on the ground - floor . TIME , finger - prints were taken . After that , ORG had been taken into the office situated on the second floor of the police station , in order to be informed about the charges .

CARDINAL . According to the official report , at TIME , after signing the notice of charges , PERSON asked to use the toilet claiming that it was urgent . It was decided that CARDINAL police officers would accompany him to the ground floor of the police building due to the fact that there were no bars at the toilet located on the second floor . On the ground floor , PERSON was not allowed to close the door of the toilet for security reasons . On the way back , police officer PERSON walked in front of PERSON and officer PERSON was on the latter ’s right holding his wrist . There are discrepancies between different statements of officers PERSON and P. as to whether officer PERSON held GPE ’s left or right wrist with his left hand . Handcuffs were not used and the grasp was not very firm due to PERSON calm behaviour . The group went without any problems through the mezzanine floor between the ground and the first floor where windows were provided with bars . When officer PERSON had already crossed the mezzanine floor between the first and the second floor and when GPE and officer PERSON were just arriving to the mezzanine floor , PERSON suddenly turned , struck with his open palm the left shoulder of the officer who held him by the wrist , broke away and jumped , head first , through a closed window into the yard . After having reeled , officer PERSON unsuccessfully attempted to catch him by the legs as they disappeared through the broken window . The police officers started to shout in order to have an ambulance called , ran out to the yard and provided , together with other officers , first aid to PERSON was taken to the hospital by ambulance and died TIME at TIME

CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG ( the “ ORG ” ) started an investigation . They inspected the scene of incident , sketched and photographed it . All participants were invited to draw an official record ( úřední záznam ) where they would comment on the incident .

An officer from ORG of the Minister of the ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) inspected the scene of incident , took explanations from the Head of ORG , police officer P. , and police officer PERSON However , she did not speak to police officer PERSON as he was being provided with necessary medical aid resulting from the assault by GPE Basing her conclusion on the preliminary findings of the control and monitoring bodies , she concluded that there were no grounds for suspecting the police officers of having committed a crime . Accordingly , the investigations were further led by ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE , the expert who established the forensic biomechanics expert report was heard by ORG . He apologized for several formal mistakes in his report but maintained that the substantial conclusions were correct . CARDINAL . On DATE the district prosecutor dismissed the ORG appeal as ill - founded . In respect of the challenged report of DATE , the district prosecutor noted that the expert had admitted that it contained errors but further noted that these had been classified as formal . The prosecutor agreed with the opinion of the regional prosecutor that ORG had most probably attempted to escape . Given that the windows were partly shaded , he could not see the concrete surface below nor could he exactly estimate the height . Thus he might have thought that it would be possible to escape . The prosecutor concluded by stating that this had only been the prosecutor ’s personal view and that the victim ’s intentions would never be known .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) stipulates that a constitutional appeal may be submitted : a ) pursuant to LAW , by a natural or legal person , if he or she alleges that his or her fundamental rights and basic freedoms guaranteed in the constitutional order have been infringed as a result of the final decision in proceedings to which he or she was a party , of a measure , or of some other encroachment by a public authority .

CARDINAL . By virtue of Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) if the Constitutional Court grants the constitutional appeal of a natural or legal person under LAW ) of the LAW , it shall : a ) quash the contested decision of the public authority , or b ) if a constitutionally guaranteed fundamental right or basic freedom was infringed as the result of an encroachment by a public authority other than a decision , enjoin the authority not to continue to infringe this right or freedom and order it , to the extent possible , to restore the situation that existed prior to the infringement .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL grants the right to just satisfaction in cases of impairment of a right guaranteed by LAW among which figure especially protection of life and health , civic honour and human dignity , privacy , name , and personal expression .
CARDINAL . Pursuant to LAW , an individual has the right to pecuniary compensation for non - pecuniary damage if the just satisfaction within the meaning of LAW is insufficient .
CARDINAL . The ORG is by virtue of LAW liable for damages inflicted by , inter alia , its authorities .

CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL ) a person who had suffered loss on account of such an irregularity was entitled to damages .

DATE entered into force amending , inter alia , section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) which newly provides that the ORG is liable for damage caused by an irregularity in the conduct of proceedings , including non - compliance with the obligation to perform an act or give a decision within the statutory time - limit . Act no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL also introduced a new section CARDINALa which provides for a reasonable satisfaction for non - pecuniary damage caused by an irregularity in the conduct of proceedings including non - compliance with the obligation to perform an act or to adopt a decision within a reasonable time .
CARDINAL . Pursuant to LAW , investigation is led by the units of ORG , unless provided otherwise . The Minister of the ORG can entrust with investigation also other entities of ORG .
CARDINAL . Pursuant to LAW an investigation ( vyšetřování ) into crimes committed by police officers is carried out by a prosecutor .
CARDINAL . Under LAW a prosecutor supervises criminal proceedings to ensure their lawfulness .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provided that criminal offences committed by police officers were investigated by ORG of the Minister of the ORG , an internal unit of ORG directly managed by the Minister .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provided that the Police was subordinated to ORG . The actions of the Police were directed by ORG , unless provided otherwise by the law , headed by the Police President . The Police President was appointed and revoked by the Minister with the approval of the Government . The Police President accounted for the acts of the Police before the Minister .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provided , inter alia , for ORG liability for bodily harm , death or damage caused to individuals by the police .

CARDINAL . Pursuant to section CARDINAL , signs indicating possible commission of a crime by police officers are to be examined ( prověřit ) by ORG headed by a director accounting to ORG . ORG is part of ORG . Its Director is appointed and revoked by the Government . ORG is composed of police officers assigned to ORG .

CARDINAL . According to this internal rule applicable within the police units subject to the Police President , suspected crimes punishable by DATE of imprisonment were to be examined ( prověřit ) by the police monitoring authorities ( kontrolní útvary PERSON ) in case of ( i ) suicide or self - harm of persons occurring in connection with the active duty interventions or other acts of police officers , and of ( ii ) signs of incidents discovered by themselves until it appears that there is suspicion that a crime has been committed by an officer or an employee of the Police in connection with the execution of their tasks .

CARDINAL . According to these internal rules , the ORG encompasses different services and units which are all directly or indirectly subordinated to the Director . These units comprise also the Complaints and Monitoring Unit , ORG , and ORG , which are however distinct units not hierarchically dependent of each other .

The Director decides , inter alia , on service and employment issues of the officers and employees . All police officers of the ORG are subordinated to him . He is the direct superior of the Director of ORG .

CARDINAL . In this decision the court rejected a victim ’s claim under LAW contesting a prosecutor ’s decision confirming suspension of an investigation of alleged police ill - treatment by ORG . It held that due to the constitutional principle of separation of powers , courts , including ORG , could not interfere with the power of the prosecutor to bring charges or not . It could only review a prosecutor ’s decision to the extent that it was arbitrary . It found that the decision of the prosecutor had been sufficiently reasoned and that the prosecutor had proceeded in accordance with LAW procedure .

CARDINAL . In this decision ORG rejected a victim ’s complaint under LAW and CARDINAL of the LAW contesting the suspension of an investigation into alleged police ill - treatment . The appellant complained that the investigation had not been independent and impartial because it had been carried out by ORG of the Minister of the ORG and only formally supervised by a prosecutor . The court held :
“ The possibility of interference by ORG with the investigation phase of criminal proceedings must be interpreted restrictively . ORG can correct only the most extreme excesses . ...

In the past , ORG occasionally stepped out of its now well - established case - law . It did so in instances when the prosecutor had failed to sufficiently reason its decision to reject the complaint against a decision of the police to bring charges ( see nos . III . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL and III . ÚS PERSON ) .

Even after the delivery of these judgments ORG does not consider that it has the power to review conduct of prosecutorial authorities regarding the substantive reasons and justification for bringing charges . It follows that only complaints claiming insufficient reasons for a decision that would suggest arbitrariness by the prosecutorial authorities can be subject to a review by ORG . ”

ORG added that , having reviewed the administrative case file , the investigation by the police authorities had been compatible with the law and that the appellant ’s procedural rights had been protected . It did not give any opinion on his complaint that the investigation had not been independent and impartial .

CARDINAL . By that judgment , the court , on appeal of the accused , quashed a prosecutor ’s decision approving the decision of the police to charge the applicant because the prosecutor had failed to examine the appellant ’s complaints efficiently and to explain the reasons for the decision . As a general principle , the court held that a decision of a prosecutor must be reasoned and he or she must properly examine the complaints . It added that it did not have the power to review the substance of a decision by a prosecutor to bring charges against an individual or to comment whether a particular criminal investigation was justified ; these were questions that fell exclusively within the power of prosecutorial authorities .

CARDINAL . In this decision ORG found that a failure by the ORG to carry out an effective investigation , within the meaning of LAW , into an alleged ill - treatment by the police , was not part of personality rights protected by LAW . Thus , civil courts could not review the issue as part of a civil action for the protection of personality rights .

DATE . On DATE , the Ministry awarded damages pursuant to LAW to a person who had suffered serious physical injuries as a consequence of being shot by a police officer . The damages were awarded after a prosecution had been brought against the police officer . ORG had acknowledged liability .

CARDINAL . The ORG recommended that the NORP Republic take appropriate measures to ensure the independence of investigations of offences committed by law - enforcement officials by introducing a mechanism of external control .

CARDINAL . The ORG expressed its concerns that complaints against the police are handled by an internal police inspectorate , while criminal investigations are handled by ORG , which has overall responsibility for the police . That system lacked , in the ORG ’s view , objectivity and credibility and would seem to facilitate impunity for police officers involved in human rights violations .
